title: Cathleen Falsani
text:
Cathleen Falsani (born September 25, 1970) is an American journalist and author. She specializes in the intersection of religion/spirituality/faith and culture, and has been a staff writer for the "<a href="Chicago%20Sun%20Times">Chicago Sun Times</a>", the "<a href="Chicago%20Tribune">Chicago Tribune</a>", "<a href="Sojourners">Sojourners</a>" magazine, <a href="Religion%20News%20Service">Religion News Service</a>, and the "<a href="Orange%20County%20Register">Orange County Register</a>" in Southern California. Falsani is the author of several non-fiction books on religious, spiritual, and cultural issues.
She was the 2005 Religion Writer of the Year, as awarded by the <a href="Religion%20Newswriters%20Association">Religion Newswriters Association</a>, and has twice been a finalist for the Templeton Religion Reporter of the Year award.
Early life and education.
Falsani was born on September 25, 1970. She holds masters degrees in journalism from the <a href="Medill%20School%20of%20Journalism">Medill School of Journalism</a> at <a href="Northwestern%20University">Northwestern University</a>, and in <a href="theology">theological studies</a> from <a href="Garrett%E2%80%93Evangelical%20Theological%20Seminary">Garrett–Evangelical Theological Seminary</a> in <a href="Evanston%2C%20Illinois">Evanston, Illinois</a>. She was born into a <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> family of Irish and Italian descent, but her parents left the Catholic church when she was 10 years old. With her younger brother, she was reared as an <a href="evangelical">evangelical</a> <a href="Protestant">Protestant</a> from grade school forward, largely in a <a href="Southern%20Baptist">Southern Baptist</a> church in <a href="Fairfield%2C%20Connecticut">Fairfield, Connecticut</a>. Falsani attended <a href="Christian%20Heritage%20School%20%28Trumbull%2C%20Connecticut%29">Christian Heritage School</a>, an evangelical Christian prep school in <a href="Trumbull%2C%20Connecticut">Trumbull, Connecticut</a>, graduating in 1988.
Career.
Falsani is the author of "The God Factor: Inside the Spiritual Lives of Public People", a collection of 32 spiritual profiles of famous "culture shapers" including <a href="Bono">Bono</a>, <a href="Elie%20Wiesel">Elie Wiesel</a>, <a href="Anne%20Rice">Anne Rice</a>, <a href="Hakeem%20Olajuwon">Hakeem Olajuwon</a>. Falsani's first book, it was published by <a href="Farrar%2C%20Straus%20%26amp%3B%20Giroux">Farrar, Straus & Giroux</a> in 2006, launching <a href="Sarah%20Crichton%20Books">Sarah Crichton Books</a>, a new imprint of the publisher. It was named among the best non-fiction books of 2006 by "<a href="The%20Christian%20Science%20Monitor">The Christian Science Monitor</a>".
Falsani joined the "Chicago Sun-Times" in September 2000, and served as the paper's religion reporter until 2007, continuing on as its religion columnist until January 13, 2010. She wrote," Sin Boldly: A Field Guide For Grace" (2008) a spiritual <a href="memoir">memoir</a> and <a href="Travel%20literature">travelogue</a> and "The Dude Abides: The Gospel According to the Coen Brothers" (2009), both published by <a href="Zondervan">Zondervan</a>.
Falsani is a correspondent and columnist for <a href="Religion%20News%20Service">Religion News Service</a> and a featured writer and correspondent for "<a href="Sojourners">Sojourners</a>". She also was web editor and director of new media for "Sojourners" from 2011 to 2012. She was the staff "faith and values" columnist for "The Orange County Register" from 2013 to 2014.
Interview with Obama on religion.
In March 2004, Falsani conducted an interview with <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a>. At the time of the interview, Obama was a <a href="state%20senator">state senator</a> from Illinois and <a href="Democratic%20Party%20of%20Illinois">democratic</a> nominee for the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">U.S. Senate</a> in the <a href="United%20States%20Senate%20election%20in%20Illinois%2C%202004">2004 election</a>. The interview focused on Obama's religious beliefs and spiritual predilections.
Personal.
The granddaughter of Italian and Irish immigrants, Falsani was born and raised in <a href="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>. Since 1997, Falsani has been married to Maurice Possley, the Pulitzer Prize–winning former "<a href="Chicago%20Tribune">Chicago Tribune</a>" investigative reporter and New York Times bestselling author. The couple has a son adopted from <a href="Malawi">Malawi</a> in 2010, and they live in <a href="Laguna%20Beach%2C%20California">Laguna Beach, California</a>.
